bibl.title: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1948

div1.p: Redd discusses the unorganized state of Carter's correspondence, noting that the papers were stored in trunks without any cataloguing system.

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Philip Showalter Hench, February 10, 1948
div1.opener:
Commissioner of Accounts and Commissioner in
Chancery of Circuit Court of Hanover County
H. CARTER REDD
ATTORNEY-AT-LAW
1104 TRAVELERS BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA.
February 10th, 1948
Dr. Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
My dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
I have your letter of February 7th together with copy of
letter to Dr. Carter and the paper giving your talk at the
University of Virginia. I have not had time to read the
paper as yet but will do so with pleasure.

Dr. Carter has written me that I might send you the
mass of letters etc., which I will do as soon as I can get
them out of storage, which means that as soon as the present
blizzard is over I will be able to do so. We are having
one snow storm after another and weather hovering around
ten to fifteen degrees above zero and we are not used to it.

I referred to the contents of the trunk as a mass.
Unfortunately, Laura Carter was one of those brilliant
types who did not need to keep things in systematic order
and the papers are just dumped into the trunks without any
regard to order or system. My aunt who was with Laura
and her father for quite a while, speaking of Laura's
habits said that when she retired at night she would step
out of her clothes and leave them right in the middle of
the floor. Looking at the trunk and chest which I have
gotten out of storage some time ago, I am reminded of what
my aunt said.

I have looked through the contents of the chest which
had a mass of stuff in no wise related to the medical work
but did come across a lot which did and I find that there
are articles many of them duplicates and frequently several
copies and also copies of correspondence which Laura had
evidently made. Where you run across this, there would
certainly be no objection to your taking out and retaining
a copy.
I hope to get them off to you in the near future.
